comments.commentBody: This is just the beginning. A slap is a very mild consequence of citizens' rage. If the prices keep rising, and politicians keep swallowing money the way they do, then there will be, and indeed there should be an uprising against the rulers. We need much more action against the useless, pathetic government that rules us. All I can say is its a good thing he was slapped.

Physical assault cannot be accepted, but when the situation becomes intolerant citizens are bound to get angry. We need not blame them for getting angry. We should get the corrupt politicians, past their utility, out of office. At least he identified the correct person.

@4 At no point did I say that the pollution level should not be mentioned. It is fine to say that Delhi is polluted. My beef is the anecdotal comparison with Beijing and giving it a false scientific veneer (especially when doubling down on the claim). I am a scientist and find this sort of reporting problematic. It is misleading and encourages people to pick a random data point to dismiss legitimate serious science (or any serious study for that matter). If I said no one asked me for a bribe on my weeklong visit to India hence bribery doesn't happen would anyone agree? It's not that hard for a journalist to find a legitimate study to back their claims. Or simply leave it at Delhi is very polluted.

As for NYT being a US paper. Of course it is, and the whole rest of the paper is devoted to it. But the mission of this section is stated clearly as a reporting "ON India and its place in the world". Again I fail to see what a criminal in the US who happened to have been of Indian extraction, or even better a Sri-Lankan American, has to do with "notes on the world's largest democracy". It's a tenuous connection at best.

Sooner these politicians realize that the tide is turning and that the Indians are not going to put up with their nonsense anymore, better it is for them as well as us. In the last six decades, the Congress party and their cronies have poisoned the Indian politics to its very core. In fact, the root of all of the current corrupt political practices can be traced back to the time when Indra Gandhi was the PM or to the congress rule even before that.

India has structural problems and to solve them, the society has to fundamentally change. Perhaps the process has already begun.

I am glad that Indian democracy has advanced to the point that a citizen can slap a minister now and not get instantly thrown in jail.

This is NOT to encourage such slapping (there are far superior ways to express your discontent....), but just an observation that the intrinsic "holiness" status that used to be automatically ascribed to politicians and elected representatives, are melting away - a very healthy sign for the maturing of Indian democracy.
A slap on the face of a government Minister is more effective than Occupy Wall Street

The sentiment expressed by this brave guy is commendable! Maybe his action of actually assaulting, even if it was only a slap, is not highly recommended because it could lead to disorder and anarchy....who needs that? But his message is loud and clear.

His action spoke volumes about the frustration and anger the general population in India must feel.

The politicians, whose salary is paid by tax-payers, should ponder a bit about the French revolution, and thank heaven the guillotine is not common in India.

Awesome, Mr. Singh, all of our current leaders deserve to be slapped!

These fat cat so called leaders have taken corruption in India to a level which boggles the common mind.

We have leaders who have long fooled the common Indians with false promises.
We need strong independent leaders, not the same BJP (Advani / Vajpayee) and Congress (Gandhi + Gandhi) formula.

They are same corrupt leader promising enough to win the election.

Does the current Indian leadership have anything new to offer? As a Indian what amazes me is how most Indians are waiting for the messiah (Rahul Gandhi) to lead our nation?
Trying to label Rahul as a "Angry Young Man", to win votes, are we so naive? Is his being born in the Gandhi family qualification enough to lead our nation?

Mr. Singh's slap is not just his frustration, but the frustration of a billion Indians with our corrupt rudderless Indian leadership.
How will the leaders address our frustration?

Here's how; Mr. Singh will be labeled a disturbed young man, there will another scandal involving billions by another Indian leader, the leader will be arrested and after a slap on his wrist will be released. The leader will stand in the next election claiming to be arrested in the first place due to a "political conspiracy" and will be re elected.

And then our nation will look towards the great "Gandhi" family to lead our nation from the quagmire of corruption, only to again give in to the same policies which has enabled corrupt politicians to fleece our nation over and over again. Our nation needs strong leaders, leaders who can think for themselves. Am not a huge fan of Narendra Modi but he seems to be the only leader we have who is self made. We need someone to question, shake up the system.

We need someone to take flak and lead the nation. Not another Manmohan Singh, who unfortunately has been a filler for the messiah Rahul Gandhi.
It is not honorable to slap a 70 year old man from behind.  The attacker has absolutely no claim to the moral high ground.
Just one man hitting one corrupt politician at a time, this will take a long time for India to improve.

Rich people don't create jobs. Democracy creates jobs, by ensuring that the wealthiest pay a progressive rate in order to support the things that enabled the acquisition of their wealth in the first place: maintained roads, good schools, good health due to good medical care. As Elizabeth Warren said, nobody in this country got rich on his or her own.

Since the United States no longer requires its extremely wealthy citizens to pay their fair share in taxes, we can only conclude that the USA is not, in fact, a democracy. It's a plutocracy run by a shadow government of, by and for the oligarchs who control the politicians and all three branches of government. Every once in awhile, we the people are allowed to vote for one of two candidates who have been vetted,groomed and monetized by said audacious oligarchs. Democracy is a sham.

According to Forbes magazine, the combined net worth of the richest 400 Americans is $1.53 trillion: nearly the equivalent of the entire GDP of Canada. The 400, all billionaires, saw their collective wealth increase by 12% just in the past year. And not only is the average effective tax rate of billionaires only an average of 18 percent, corporations do even better. Many of the largest, including GE, not only pay zero taxes, but they themselves write the tax laws to award themselves subsidies payable by us, the 99% -- or 99.9%.

To add insult to injury, the wealthiest family on the planet -- the Waltons -- are making sure they suck every last dollar from consumers, and the very life out of their poorly paid employees, by opening their stores at 10 p.m. Thanksgiving night, creating mindless stampedes of desperate people who have been led to believe that a $200 flat screen TV from China is the epitome of the American dream.

And yes, Black Friday is being Occupied too.

http://kmgarcia2000.blogspot.com/

Considering that the 0.01% have control of our own economy, it's not a stretch to realize that they have control over ALL economies, too... and thus, they control the entire Earth.

Let's just follow the money, shall we? Let's find out where the strings are being manipulated, and by whom, cut them once and for all, and get on with constructing a world economy in which the 99.99% -- We the People -- come first, last, and always.

Seems to me ESC for "Way out: Abbr." is sort of messed up. If the abbreviation is for escape, and it is used as a noun, it doesn't mean "way out". "Escape route" does .... If escape is meant as a verb, it does not match the usage of "way out", which is a noun or adjective not meaning escape. Even on Friday, maybe stick to clues like "upper left key" or something. If 'way out" is meant to mean the ESC key, then it is not an abbreviation. The key's name is ESC.

Other than that nit, I really like the 4-stack of 15s. Nice puzzle Joe.

I agree with Joy.  This whole project it a lot more fun with all of you to chat with.  We had a lovely Thanksgiving leg of lamb here in MN and a lovely warm day to boot.  Best to you all. KP

I'm having a hard time unwinding, so I am here to read late comments. A busy day, leading me to conclude that maybe it IS better to travel than to host a feast. I used to do all of this virtually on my own, but this year I find myself exhausted from two days of preparations and feasting. I made a bid to serve green salad instead of green beans, and was roundly reproached for messing with family tradition. (I was also told I did not make enough gravy to last through all the left-overs!) And then, after 40+ years of baking, I left the yeast out of the yeast biscuits! Word to the wise: it doesn't work that well to try and incorporate it later! On the other hand, the fruitcake got raves, and everyone ate so much that no one wanted supper. We followed our tradition of talking about what each of us is most grateful for this year.....Counting our blessings!

And I am thankful for WordPlay and our intrepid puzzle-makers.

"Congress must not lose sight of the bigger picture: the need to invest in promising alternatives to fossil fuels."

This conclusion appears obvious, but it has been our experience since the midterm elections (actually, before) that the "Big Picture" continues to elude our illustrious Congress.

Perhaps re-election donations from the petrochemical industry are clouding the future, where alternative energy sources either exist in abundance... or war over scarce resources escalates and expands.

Every energy company in America should already be pursuing alternatives, and any Congressperson should be helping in that effort wherever possible; survival is not up for debate.

Thanks, Andy. Those examples were blood-curdling. I guess the more subtle argument is whether the rise of organized sports is just a symptom of the trend toward greater civility or whether it played a bigger role, as a substitute for conflict that helped make change. Lacrosse among American Indians is an interesting example. It was sometimes used to settle disputes and prevent warring among the Iroquois nations. During the World Cup, I think most people would be too busy watching soccer to fight. The more sports, the merrier, it seems.

Somehow the words 'passionate environmentalist' and hunter do not seem to go well together. What is missing is the appreciation that they are sentient beings and we no longer have to hunt to have enough protein in our diets.

With elk, I have seen how skittish they become when around human beings, and have read that stress can lead to still born and miscarried calves. Human beings are ultimate stealth hunters, many seemingly unaware or uncaring that these random killings - from the perspective of the elk - seriously disrupts their lives and their tranquility, such as it is, while enduring all kinds of harsh weather and predation by wolves. Do we really want or need to add to their life burdens?

We should be so lucky as to have Argentina's problem of an "overheated" economy.

I'd love to have someone to vote for who would try to heat our economy up. But the only choices are between folks looking to tank it -- supposedly out of fear of inflation.
